results.title: Inheriting
results.brief_description: Arika Waulu has inherited quite a lot in her young life. A young fighter for social justice, her inheritance is two-fold. She inherited her land from her ancestors and her sense of social justice from her parents. But rather than take these things for granted, Arika embraces them.

results.title: Triptych
results.creator_credit: Walter Bird, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Walter Bird recalls a time when he was asked “Where are you from?”, and answered by describing where his house was situated in the neighbourhood. Growing up, he started to learn the implications of that question. He realised that he was ethnically different from other Australian-born children. Being the child of immigrants, Walter weighs up the positives and negatives of being a first generation Australian and shares his experiences when he finally travelled to his parents’ countries.

results.title: The Invisible net
results.creator_credit: Sarah Vincent, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Sarah Vincent looks at 2008, a year of immense ups and downs, and, in particular, when she was diagnosed with cancer. Rather than dwelling on the treatment and anxiety, Sarah chooses to focus on the amazing support she received from her community of family, friends, the school and neighbours. Through their support, Sarah learned to count her blessings and credits cancer with changing her outlook on life.

results.title: Old life, new life
results.creator_credit: Raelanah Loloa, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: For Raelanah Loloa, moving from the town where she grew up in New Zealand to start a new life in Australia was an experience both exciting and stressful. It was hard leaving all her friends and trying to make new ones but, eventually, Raelanah and her family were able to build a new life in Australia.

results.title: From fear to success
results.creator_credit: Phillip Martinovski, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Phillip Martinovski had to go to Copperfield’s senior campus, he was incredibly nervous, so much so that on the first day he spent a lot of time standing outside the gates, debating whether to ‘wag’. In the end, he threw himself him and talks about his time at Copperfield College Senior School, in the hope that he can students like him overcome their fears.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phillip Martinovski, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Change
results.creator_credit: Michelle Huynh, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Michelle Huynh’s high school years were peppered with having to change schools. In that, she had to adjust to a new area, and more importantly, make new friends. In time, Michelle has learnt to see the changes she dreaded so much as a good thing.

results.title: Never give up
results.creator_credit: Haris Fazlic, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Haris Fazlic got sick of being larger than his classmates and took up exercising and, eventually, discovered his passion for wrestling. This passion has driven him to win many times despite having to overcome a major obstacle on the way. Wrestling has taught Haris that you should never give up on something you love, no matter what.

results.title: My special family
results.creator_credit: Erin Wilson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Erin Wilson pays tribute to her special family, a family who have taught her all about life. From her family, Erin has learnt responsibility, empathy, the realities of life and death and, most importantly, love and friendship. Here she pays tribute to the members of this special family.

results.title: Complications
results.creator_credit: Brook Tesfaye, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Brook Tesfaye was born with one complicaton - his left foot was bent. Since his parents couldn’t afford surgery in Switzerland, Brook wore plastic correcting shoes for seven years, until he finally got his foot straight. He talks about the ongoing complications of the bent foot, of the pain, discomfit and subsequent complicatons on his knee and ankle, and how he has lived his life regardless. Despite the pain, Brook is determined to continue playing soccer, a passion he can never give up. He figures that’s how life is - and everyone has their complications.
